body: **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** I want to use local files with Argila. **Describe the solution you'd like** ```python import base64 from pathlib import Path def get_file_type(path): return Path(path).suffix[1:] def video_to_dataurl(path, file_type: str = None): # Open the video file and read its contents with open(path, 'rb') as f: video_data = f.read() # Encode the video data as base64 video_base64 = base64.b64encode(video_data).decode('utf-8') # Get the file type (e.g. mp4) file_type = file_type or get_file_type(path) # Prepend the Data URL prefix to the base64-encoded data data_url = f'data:video/{file_type};base64,' + video_base64 # Create HTML html = f"" html_href = f"Click" html_iframe = f"" html_embed = f"" return html_embed def audio_to_dataurl(path, file_type: str = None): # Open the audio file and read its contents with open(path, 'rb') as f: audio_data = f.read() # Encode the audio data as base64 audio_base64 = base64.b64encode(audio_data).decode('utf-8') # Get the file type (e.g. mp3) file_type = file_type or get_file_type(path) # Prepend the Data URL prefix to the base64-encoded data data_url = f'data:audio/{file_type};base64,' + audio_base64 # Create HTML html = f"" return html def image_to_dataurl(path, file_type: str = None): # open the image file and read its contents with open(path, 'rb') as f: image_data = f.read() # Encode the image data as base64 image_base64 = base64.b64encode(image_data).decode('utf-8') # Get the file type (e.g. png) file_type = file_type or get_file_type(path) # Prepend the Data URL prefix to the base64-encoded data data_url = f'data:image/{file_type};base64,' + image_base64 # Create HTML html = f'' return HTML ``` **Describe alternatives you've considered** N.A. **Additional context** The image one is not working in FireFox but does seem to work in Safari.

title: Fix: add metadata property for datasets without metadata properties already defined
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR fixes this workflow:
```python
ds = rg.FeedbackDataset.for_supervised_fine_tuning(
    context=True,
    use_markdown=True,
    guidelines=None,
    #metadata=metadata # I've just created a feature request for this
)
​
# In the meantime I want to update a dataset I've just created
metadata = [rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="one_of_my_col", title="One of my col")]
for m in metadata:
  ds.add_metadata_property(m)
```

The `__init__` method defines an empty list for `_metadata_properties` attribute if `None` was passed. Otherwise, an error occurs when adding a new metadata property.

title: feat: add `last_activity_at` to feedback datasets
body:
# Description

This PR adds a new `DateTime` column to `datasets` table with name `last_activity_at`.

This new column will be updated for the following cases:
* When a dataset is created or updated.
* When a response for a record belonging to the dataset has been created, updated or deleted.

The idea is that we can use `last_activity_at` to record the last time that an activity associated with a dataset happened and use it instead of `updated_at` to show recent activity on the UI.

Closes #3981

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendly.com/natalia-elvira/30min -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
- When I want to swap around `FeedbackRecord` and their equivalent `RemoteFeedbackRecord` they don't play nicely. For example, the  `RemoteFeedbackRecord` has unserializable objects.
- The `RemoteFeedbackRecord.delete()` method usage does not provide a clear overview of the fact that it return a `FeedbackRecord`.
- The `RemoteFeedbackRecord` has an `update()` method for just suggestions, but has a separate `delete_suggestions()` method. 
- The local `FeedbackRecord` only has the `update()` method, but not `__update_suggestions()` or `delete_suggestions()`.
- The local `FeedbackRecord` does not have all the properties the `RemoteFeedbackRecord` has.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A similar approach as we did for the alignment of the datasets themselves.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N.A.

**Additional context**
As an internal developer, I do get why these choices were made but as a new person trying this, I think I would not understand and maybe look at something that does work out-of-the-box.

```[tasklist]
### Tasks
- [ ] align addition and update methods add_suggestions, add_responses, add_metadata
- [ ] align deletion methods
- [ ] deprecate `FeedbackRecord.update` and use validation on item assignement
```

title: [FEATURE] Add `last_activity_at` to Feedback Datasets

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
Right now feedback datasets are exposing internal database `updated_at` attribute with the timestamp of the moment the dataset was updated.

This is not really useful for users so we want to add a new `last_activity_at` attribute to feedback datasets with the timestamp of the last updated response.

`last_activity_at` will be updated with the following cases:
* The dataset has been created.
* The dataset has been updated.
* A response for a record belonging to the dataset has been created.
* A response for a record belonging to the dataset has been updated.
* A response for a record belonging to the dataset has been deleted.

This feature will require changes on the frontend to use `last_activity_at` instead of `updated_at` for feedback datasets. 

/cc @damianpumar

body:
# Description

This PR adds a new method `push_to_huggingface` to the `ArgillaTrainer` to simplify uploading the trained models to the [huggingface model hub](https://huggingface.co/models).

This option is implemented for the following models:
- [x] `transformers`
- [x] `peft`
- [x] `setfit`
- [x] `spacy`
- [x] `spacy-transformers`
- [x] `trl`
- [ ] `sentence_transformers`
       This framework doesn't work as of currently. The following message is written at the corresponding test:
       *This framework is not implemented yet. Cross-Encoder models don't implement the functionality*
       *for pushing a model to huggingface, and SentenceTransformer models have the functionality*
       *but is outdated and doesn't work with the current versions of 'huggingface-hub'.*
       *The present test is let here for the future, when we either implement the functionality*
       *in 'argilla', or 'sentence-transformers'.*
- [ ] `openai`
     *Doesn't apply*

Closes #3633

<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
When using ArgillaTrainer with transformers framework and a FeedbackDataset created manually, it just returns the error below stating that the "answer" is not found in the dictionary.
If tried with from_huggingface method as in `dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_huggingface("argilla/squad")`, it works just fine.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**
```python
import argilla as rg
from argilla.feedback import ArgillaTrainer, TrainingTask
from datasets import load_dataset

dataset_from_hf = load_dataset("argilla/squad", split="train").shard(num_shards=10000, index=1)
dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[rg.TextField(name="question"), rg.TextField(name="context")],
    questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="answer")]
)

records = [rg.FeedbackRecord(
    fields={"question": item["question"],
            "context": item["context"],
            "answer": item["answer"][0]["value"]}
  ) for item in dataset_from_hf
]

dataset.add_records(records)

task = TrainingTask.for_question_answering(question=dataset.field_by_name("question"),
                                           context=dataset.field_by_name("context"),
                                           answer=dataset.question_by_name("answer"),
                                           )
trainer = ArgillaTrainer(
    dataset=dataset,
    task=task,
    framework="transformers",
)
```

title: feat: add `update_metadata_properties` in `FeedbackDataset` and `RemoteFeedbackDataset`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

This PR adds the `update_metadata_property` function in the Python SDK to call the `PATCH /api/v1/metadata-properties/{metadata_property_id}` endpoint, also adding the `update` method to the `ArgillaMetadataPropertiesMixin` that contains some common functionality for the remote `metadata_properties` i.e. `metadata_properties` from a `RemoteFeedbackDataset` which is a `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla.

So on, now anyone with either `owner` or `admin` roles can perform updates of the `metadata_properties` via assignment and then push those updates to Argilla via `update_metadata_properties`. Note that the schemas define an in-place method named `_update` which applies to any of `RemoteTermsMetadataProperty`, `RemoteIntegerMetadataProperty`, and `RemoteFloatMetadataProperty`, on any or both of the `title` value and the `visible_for_annotators` flag.

Closes #3960 

## Code-snippet

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(api_url="...", api_key="...")

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[rg.TextField(name="required-field", required=True), rg.TextField(name="optional-field", required=False)],
    questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="question", required=True)],
    metadata_properties=[
        rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="terms-metadata", title="old-title", values=["a", "b", "c"]),
        rg.IntegerMetadataProperty(name="int-metadata", min=0, max=10),
        rg.FloatMetadataProperty(name="float-metadata", min=0.0, max=10.0),
    ],
)

metadata_property = dataset.metadata_property_by_name(name="terms-metadata")
metadata_property.title = "new-title"
metadata_property.visible_for_annotators = False

remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")
print(remote_dataset.metadata_properties)

remote_metadata_property = remote_dataset.metadata_property_by_name(name="terms-metadata")
remote_metadata_property.title = "old-title"
remote_metadata_property.visible_for_annotators = True

remote_dataset.update_metadata_properties(remote_metadata_property)
print(remote_dataset.metadata_properties)
```

> **⚠️ Warning:** the code below will fail on `RemoteFeedbackDataset` because the `metadata_properties` are fetched every time those are accessed and the values are not persisted in Argilla until one calls `update_metadata_properties` with one or multiple `metadata_properties` with updated attributes.

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(api_url="...", api_key="...")

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[rg.TextField(name="required-field", required=True), rg.TextField(name="optional-field", required=False)],
    questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="question", required=True)],
    metadata_properties=[
        rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="terms-metadata", title="old-title", values=["a", "b", "c"]),
        rg.IntegerMetadataProperty(name="int-metadata", min=0, max=10),
        rg.FloatMetadataProperty(name="float-metadata", min=0.0, max=10.0),
    ],
)

remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")

remote_dataset.metadata_properties[0].title = "new-title"
assert remote_dataset.metadata_properties[0].title == "new-title"

for remote_metadata_property in remote_dataset.metadata_properties:
   remote_metadata_property.title = "new-title"
assert all(
    remote_metadata_property.title == "new-title" for remote_metadata_property in remote_dataset.metadata_properties
)
```

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [x] Add integration tests for `update_metadata_property` in the Python SDK
- [x] Add unit and integration tests for `update_metadata_properties` in the Python client
- [x] Add integration tests for `Remote{Terms,Integer,Float}MetadataProperty._update` in the Python client

**Checklist**

- [x] I added relevant documentation
- [x] I followed the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I did a self-review of my code
- [ ] I made corresponding changes to the documentation
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings
- [x] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [ ] I filled out [the contributor form](https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK) (see text above)
- [x] I have added relevant notes to the `CHANGELOG.md` file (See https://keepachangelog.com/)

title: [FEATURE] Add `update` for `Remote{Terms,Integer,Float}MetadataProperties`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
## Description

The remote metadata properties i.e. `RemoteTermsMetadataProperty`, `RemoteIntegerMetadataProperty`, and `RemoteFloatMetadataProperty`, should allow in-place updates in case we want to modify either the `title` (what's shown in the UI), or the `visible_for_annotators` flag.

This issue is a follow up of the `PATCH /api/v1/metadata-properties/{metadata_property_id}` endpoint created as of https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3952.

Note that the `update` should just be allowed to users with either `owner` or `admin` roles.

title: [BUG-UI/UX] Field not shown in the order defined in the dataset settings

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body: **Describe the bug** I define the order for my field during the configuration step with the SDK. When I add records with the fields dictionary and the keys in a different order, the fields are shown in the UI following the order of the dict keys (I suppose) instead of the list ordering defined during the configuration. Dataset settings for fields are shown in the correct order (in the UI). **To Reproduce** # 👎🏼 Shown in incorrect order ```python import argilla as rg rg.init( api_key="admin.apikey", api_url="https://argilla-metadata.hf.space" ) dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset( fields=[rg.TextField(name="text"), rg.TextField(name="response")], questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="text_question")], ) dataset.add_records( records=[ rg.FeedbackRecord( fields={"response": "I should be second", "text": "I should be first"} ) ] ) dataset.push_to_argilla(name="field-wrong-order-2", workspace="admin") ``` or see https://argilla-metadata.hf.space/dataset/bbdde002-b30b-46d6-a769-83e856ec3ad7/annotation-mode?_search=&_page=1&_status=pending # ✅ Shown in correct order ```python import argilla as rg rg.init( api_key="admin.apikey", api_url="https://argilla-metadata.hf.space" ) dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset( fields=[rg.TextField(name="text"), rg.TextField(name="response")], questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="text_question")], ) dataset.add_records( records=[ rg.FeedbackRecord( fields={"text": "I should be first", "response": "I should be second", } ) ] ) dataset.push_to_argilla(name="field-wrong-order-2", workspace="admin") ``` or see: https://argilla-metadata.hf.space/dataset/8d32a846-92f2-4665-beb6-52b384168b7c/annotation-mode?_search=&_page=1&_status=pending **Expected behavior** The list ordering when I configure the fields should be kept, irrespective of the order of the dict keys (which should be unordered anyway) **Screenshots** **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS [e.g. iOS]: MacOS - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Brave - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.16.0 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: quickstart **Additional context** Add any other context about the problem here.

<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR adds the record metadata validation when records are updated using `update_records`. 

This validation is not included in `record.update` since the dataset must be visible at a record level and many changes must be applied.  It will be applied in a separate PR


Also, the server metadata property validation for numeric properties has been fixed when passing unparseable numbers ("wrong-float" or "wrong-integer", for example)


Refs #3748

title: [FEATURE] Review and improve HTTP headers sent by client

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: server
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the server

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Right now the internal `httpx` client used by the Argilla client is sending the following headers in all the HTTP requests to the server:

```
Host: localhost:6900
Accept: */*
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Connection: keep-alive
User-Agent: python-httpx/0.23.3
Authorization: Bearer API_KEY
X-Argilla-Api-Key: API_KEY
```

The value of the `User-Agent` shouldn't depend on the version of the `httpx` library installed and it should be something like `argilla-python-client/1.17.0`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
```
Host: localhost:6900
Accept: */*
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Connection: keep-alive
User-Agent: argilla-python-client/1.17.0
Authorization: Bearer API_KEY
X-Argilla-Api-Key: API_KEY
```

and document the headers sent by the client in the docs.

title: fix(test): add `target_modules` for `peft`

labels.name: area: tests
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the tests

labels.name: type: integration
labels.description: Indicates integrations with third parties

body:
# Description

This PR fixes an integration test that is failing because the `target_modules` were not provided to `peft` when defining the `LoraConfig` which can potentially be internally inferred for some known models, but for some others there's no existing mapping, so those need to be specifically provided.

On top of that, the existing assertion to ensure that the provided model and tokenizer to `peft` were being used was not working correctly, so it has been removed for the `model` as it's not required since `peft` uses the model to generate the adapters, and regarding the tokenizer a simple assertion on the `pretrained_init_configuration` does the work.

Closes #3940

title: build(deps-dev): update httpx requirement from <0.24,>=0.15 to >=0.15,<0.26

labels.name: type: dependencies
labels.description: Indicates a pull request that updates a dependency file

labels.name: language: python
labels.description: Pull requests or issues that update Python code

body:
Updates the requirements on [httpx](https://github.com/encode/httpx) to permit the latest version.
Release notes

Sourced from httpx's releases.

Version 0.25.0

0.25.0 (11th Sep, 2023)

Removed

  • Drop support for Python 3.7. (#2813)

Added

  • Support HTTPS proxies. (#2845)
  • Change the type of Extensions from Mapping[Str, Any] to MutableMapping[Str, Any]. (#2803)
  • Add socket_options argument to httpx.HTTPTransport and httpx.AsyncHTTPTransport classes. (#2716)
  • The Response.raise_for_status() method now returns the response instance. For example: data = httpx.get('...').raise_for_status().json(). (#2776)

Fixed

  • Return 500 error response instead of exceptions when raise_app_exceptions=False is set on ASGITransport. (#2669)
  • Ensure all WSGITransport environs have a SERVER_PROTOCOL. (#2708)
  • Always encode forward slashes as %2F in query parameters (#2723)
  • Use Mozilla documentation instead of httpstatuses.com for HTTP error reference (#2768)
Changelog

Sourced from httpx's changelog.

0.25.0 (11th Sep, 2023)

Removed

  • Drop support for Python 3.7. (#2813)

Added

  • Support HTTPS proxies. (#2845)
  • Change the type of Extensions from Mapping[Str, Any] to MutableMapping[Str, Any]. (#2803)
  • Add socket_options argument to httpx.HTTPTransport and httpx.AsyncHTTPTransport classes. (#2716)
  • The Response.raise_for_status() method now returns the response instance. For example: data = httpx.get('...').raise_for_status().json(). (#2776)

Fixed

  • Return 500 error response instead of exceptions when raise_app_exceptions=False is set on ASGITransport. (#2669)
  • Ensure all WSGITransport environs have a SERVER_PROTOCOL. (#2708)
  • Always encode forward slashes as %2F in query parameters (#2723)
  • Use Mozilla documentation instead of httpstatuses.com for HTTP error reference (#2768)

0.24.1 (17th May, 2023)

Added

  • Provide additional context in some InvalidURL exceptions. (#2675)

Fixed

  • Fix optional percent-encoding behaviour. (#2671)
  • More robust checking for opening upload files in binary mode. (#2630)
  • Properly support IP addresses in NO_PROXY environment variable. (#2659)
  • Set default file for NetRCAuth() to None to use the stdlib default. (#2667)
  • Set logging request lines to INFO level for async requests, in line with sync requests. (#2656)
  • Fix which gen-delims need to be escaped for path/query/fragment components in URL. (#2701)

0.24.0 (6th April, 2023)

Changed

  • The logging behaviour has been changed to be more in-line with other standard Python logging usages. We no longer have a custom TRACE log level, and we no longer use the HTTPX_LOG_LEVEL environment variable to auto-configure logging. We now have a significant amount of DEBUG logging available at the network level. Full documentation is available at https://www.python-httpx.org/logging/ (#2547, encode/httpcore#648)
  • The Response.iter_lines() method now matches the stdlib behaviour and does not include the newline characters. It also resolves a performance issue. (#2423)
  • Query parameter encoding switches from using + for spaces and %2F for forward slash, to instead using %20 for spaces and treating forward slash as a safe, unescaped character. This differs from requests, but is in line with browser behavior in Chrome, Safari, and Firefox. Both options are RFC valid. (#2543)
  • NetRC authentication is no longer automatically handled, but is instead supported by an explicit httpx.NetRCAuth() authentication class. See the documentation at https://www.python-httpx.org/advanced/#netrc-support (#2525)

Removed

  • The rfc3986 dependancy has been removed. (#2252)

0.23.3 (4th Jan, 2023)

title: feat: include `metadata_properties` in `DatasetConfig` on `{push_to,from}_huggingface`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

This PR adds the `metadata_properties` in the `DatasetConfig` in order to dump and load those from the Hugging Face Hub via `push_to_huggingface` and `from_huggingface`, respectively.

Besides that, the `metadata_properties` have been defined as `Annotated(..., discriminator="type")`, which implies that the types defined in the `pydantic.BaseModel` schemas for the `metadata_properties` i.e. `TermsMetadataProperty`, `IntegerMetadataProperty`, and `FloatMetadataProperty`; the `type` has been defined as a `Literal`, to allow it to be used as `discriminator`.

Closes #3838

## Code-snippet

```python
from argilla.client.feedback.dataset import FeedbackDataset
from argilla.client.feedback.schemas.fields import TextField
from argilla.client.feedback.schemas.questions import TextQuestion, RatingQuestion, LabelQuestion, MultiLabelQuestion, RankingQuestion
from argilla.client.feedback.schemas.records import FeedbackRecord, SuggestionSchema, ResponseSchema
from argilla.client.feedback.schemas.metadata import TermsMetadataProperty, IntegerMetadataProperty, FloatMetadataProperty

dataset = FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[
        TextField(name="field-1", required=True),
        TextField(name="field-2", required=False),
    ],
    questions=[
        TextQuestion(name="question-1", required=True),
        RatingQuestion(name="question-2", required=False, values=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
        LabelQuestion(name="question-3", required=False, labels=["label-1", "label-2", "label-3"]),
        MultiLabelQuestion(name="question-4", required=False, labels=["label-1", "label-2", "label-3"], visible_labels=4),
        RankingQuestion(name="question-5", required=False, values=["label-1", "label-2", "label-3"]),
    ],
    metadata_properties=[
        TermsMetadataProperty(name="meta-1", values=["term-1", "term-2", "term-3"]),
        IntegerMetadataProperty(name="meta-2", min=0, max=10),
        FloatMetadataProperty(name="meta-3", min=0.0, max=10.0),
    ],
    guidelines="These are the guidelines",
)

dataset.add_records([
    FeedbackRecord(
        fields={
            "field-1": "value-1",
            "field-2": "value-2",
        },
        responses=[
            ResponseSchema(
                values={
                    "question-1": {"value": "response-1"},
                    "question-2": {"value": 1},
                    "question-3": {"value": "label-1"},
                    "question-4": {"value": ["label-1", "label-2"]},
                    "question-5": {"value": [{"rank": 1, "value": "label-1"}, {"rank": 2, "value": "label-2"}, {"rank": 3, "value": "label-3"}]},
                },
                status="submitted",
            ),
        ],
        suggestions=[
            SuggestionSchema(
                question_name="question-1",
                value="suggestion-1",
            ),
            SuggestionSchema(
                question_name="question-2",
                value=1,
            ),
            SuggestionSchema(
                question_name="question-3",
                value="label-1",
            ),
            SuggestionSchema(
                question_name="question-4",
                value=["label-1", "label-2"],
            ),
            SuggestionSchema(
                question_name="question-5",
                value=[{"rank": 1, "value": "label-1"}, {"rank": 2, "value": "label-2"}, {"rank": 3, "value": "label-3"}],
            ),
        ],
        metadata={
            "meta-1": "term-1",
            "meta-2": 5,
            "meta-3": 5.5,
        },
        external_id="entry-1",
    )
])

dataset.push_to_huggingface(repo_id="<HUGGING_FACE_HUB_REPO_ID>", private=True, token="<HUGGING_FACE_HUB_TOKEN>")
```

title: feat: Support for update records from SDK

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR introduces support for updating records from Python SDK. The records update workflow has 2 ways to be implemented. In this PR both are supported:
Single update:
```python
records = ds.records[:100]
for record in records:
   record.metadata.update({"new": "metadata"})
   record.update() 
```
or batch update:
```python
records = ds.records[:100]
for record in records:
   record.metadata.update({"new": "metadata"})
   record.suggestions = [...]

ds.update_records(records)
```
This is still compatible with previous record update functionality (where only suggestions could be updated)

```python
for record in records:
   record.update(suggestions=[...])
```

In order to support this, some changes have been introduced affecting records immutability, which is now removed. The reason behind this is to provide a similar way to update local and remote records (change your data at record level and then call the `update_records` method) since the `record.update` method is only available for synced/remote entities.

The metadata validation is still missing on the record update and will be tackled as a separate PR since extra changes could be potentially introduced.

Refs #3748

title: [REFACTOR] Align `@abstractmethod` definition within `argilla`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

As of the [Python documentation](https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/abc.html#abc.abstractproperty) the usage of `@abstractproperty` is discouraged and deprecated since Python 3.3, so we should stop using those in the first place, replacing them with `@property` + `@abstractmethod`.

Then regarding the body of those `@abstractmethod`s we should define an standard way of defining those.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

- Adding a one-line docstring
  
  ```python
  from abc import abstractmethod
  
  class A:
     ...
  
     @abstractmethod
     def implement_me(self) -> None:
        """This is a docstring"""
  ```

- Adding `pass`

  ```python
  from abc import abstractmethod
  
  class A:
     ...
  
     @abstractmethod
     def implement_me(self) -> None:
        pass
  ```
- Adding `...`

  ```python
  from abc import abstractmethod
  
  class A:
     ...
  
     @abstractmethod
     def implement_me(self) -> None:
        ...
  ```

title: [FEATURE] Move CLI commands under `argilla server`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: cli
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Command Line Interface (CLI)

labels.name: type: refactor
labels.description: Indicates internal refactoring of the code-base

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I think it's a bit counter-intuitive to have some server-related commands in the CLI under a different entry-point e.g. `argilla login` is login into an Argilla server, as well as `argilla logout` so those should be `argilla server login` and `argilla server logout` IMO.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Here I list some CLI commands I would just move under `server`:

- `argilla login` -> `argilla server login`
- `argilla info` -> `argilla server info`
- `argilla logout` -> `argilla server logout`

Eventually, we would also add a new command to replace `argilla info` to display local information such as the Python package version, but could be extended to any other arg we feel like can be useful.

And we should re-write the `ISSUE_TEMPLATES` to let users know that to run `argilla server info` (former `argilla info`) they need to `argilla server login` (former `argilla login`) first.

title: feat: Some feedback dataset improvements
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

The main improvements that this PR brings are:

1. **Feedback dataset class method unification**: All expected methods are defined in the base class, so they must be available for each dataset implementation. For those cases where the method has less sense or is not implemented yet, the user will be notified with a warning (@davidberenstein1957 review and improve, please)
2. **More general workflow with response unification**: The unification workflow support dataset connected to Argilla. This means that the `prepare_for_training` can be applied with remote datasets. The `unify_responses` returns a dataset where responses are unified. As a common practice, returning data is preferable to modifying values internally. We can avoid weird side effects. So, the unification workflow should be as:
```python
from argilla import MultiLabelQuestionStrategy, FeedbackDataset
​
dataset = FeedbackDataset.from_argilla(name="my-dataset")
strategy = MultiLabelQuestionStrategy("majority") # "disagreement", "majority_weighted (WIP)"

unified_dataset = dataset.unify_responses(
    question=dataset.question_by_name("tags"),
    strategy=strategy,
)

unified_dataset...
```

title: feat: add `PATCH /api/v1/dataset/{dataset_id}/records` endpoint

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
# Description

This PR adds the following:

- Updates `PATCH /api/v1/records/{record_id}` added in #3920 allowing also to update the suggestions of a record. The suggestions in the input payload will **replace** the old suggestions.
- Add new `PATCH /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records` endpoint allowing to batch/bulk update the records of a dataset. The endpoint allow to update the same attributes from the record as in the `PATCH /api/v1/records/{record_id}` endpoint.
- Slightly modify the `SearchDocument` getter dict to do not try to populate the `SearchDocument.responses` attribute if the relationship has not been loaded (this allows us to not to have to load the `Record.responses` when updating the record document in the `SearchEngine` using `add_records`)
- Removes `SearchEngine.update_record_metadata` method as the same logic is covered by `SearchEngine.add_records` method, which can be also used to update the fields of an existing document.
- Rename `SearchEngine.add_records` method to `SearchEngine.index_records` as it can be used to both add and update records.

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

I made an small benchmark to test the latency of the new endpoint. I've created a dataset with 100000 records and all the possible questions and metadata properties. Then I built batches of 1000 records, updating all the responses and metadata fields, and sent them to the API. The average response time of the bulk `PATCH` endpoint was ~= 0.8 seconds. 

<details>
  <summary>Code used for benchmark</summary>

  ```python
import uuid
import random
import argilla as rg

LABELS = ["a", "b", "c"]
RANKS = ["top-1", "top-2", "top-3"]

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[rg.TextField(name="text")],
    questions=[
        rg.TextQuestion(name="text"),
        rg.RatingQuestion(name="rating", values=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]),
        rg.LabelQuestion(name="label", labels=LABELS),
        rg.MultiLabelQuestion(name="multi-label", labels=LABELS),
        rg.RankingQuestion(name="ranking", values=RANKS),
    ],
    metadata_properties=[
        rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="label", values=LABELS),
        rg.IntegerMetadataProperty(name="integer", min=0, max=10),
        rg.FloatMetadataProperty(name="float", min=0, max=10),
    ],
)

dataset.add_records([rg.FeedbackRecord(fields={"text": "Hello"}, metadata={"extra": "yes"}) for _ in range(100000)])

remote = dataset.push_to_argilla(name=f"benchmark-{uuid.uuid4()}", workspace="gabriel")


def random_rank_order():
    ranks = RANKS.copy()
    ranks.sort(key=lambda x: random.random())
    return [{"value": rank, "rank": i + 1} for i, rank in enumerate(ranks)]


def build_update_payload(record):
    return {
        "id": str(record.id),
        "external_id": str(uuid.uuid4()),
        "metadata": {
            "label": random.choice(["a", "b", "c"]),
            "integer": random.randint(0, 10),
            "float": random.uniform(0, 10),
        },
        "suggestions": [
            {"question_id": str(remote.questions[0].id), "value": "hello world" * random.randint(1, 15)},
            {"question_id": str(remote.questions[1].id), "value": random.randint(1, 5)},
            {"question_id": str(remote.questions[2].id), "value": random.choice(["a", "b", "c"])},
            {"question_id": str(remote.questions[3].id), "value": [random.choice(["a", "b", "c"])]},
            {"question_id": str(remote.questions[4].id), "value": random_rank_order()},
        ],
    }

http_client = rg.active_client().http_client

elapseds = []

batch = []
for record in remote.records:
    batch.append(build_update_payload(record))

    if len(batch) == 1000:
        response = http_client.httpx.patch(f"/api/v1/datasets/{remote.id}/records", json={"items": batch})
        elapseds.append(response.elapsed.total_seconds())
        batch = []

average_elapsed_time = sum(elapseds) / len(elapseds)

print("Average elapsed time", average_elapsed_time)


  ```
</details>

**Checklist**

title: feat: add `delete_metadata_properties` and `_RemoteMetadataProperty.delete`

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

This PR adds both the method `delete_metadata_properties` shared by both the `FeedbackDataset` and the `RemoteFeedbackDataset`, and also the `pydantic.BaseModel` named `_RemoteMetadataProperty` that implements the method `delete` to be able to delete a `metadata_property` from a `RemoteFeedbackDataset` in-place i.e. a `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla.

## Code-snippet

* Delete `metadata_properties` locally
  ```python
  import argilla as rg
  
  dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
      fields=[...],
      questions=[...],
      metadata_properties=[
          TermsMetadataProperty(name="terms-metadata", values=["a", "b", "c"]),
          IntegerMetadataProperty(name="integer-metadata", min=0, max=10),
          FloatMetadataProperty(name="float-metadata", min=0, max=10),
      ],
  )
  
  deleted_metadata_properties = dataset.delete_metadata_properties(["terms-metadata", "integer-metadata", "float-metadata"])
  ```

* Delete `metadata_properties` remotely
  ```python
  import argilla as rg
  
  dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
      fields=[...],
      questions=[...],
      metadata_properties=[
          TermsMetadataProperty(name="terms-metadata", values=["a", "b", "c"]),
          IntegerMetadataProperty(name="integer-metadata", min=0, max=10),
          FloatMetadataProperty(name="float-metadata", min=0, max=10),
      ],
  )
  remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")
  
  # Alternative 1 -> via `delete_metadata_properties`
  deleted_metadata_properties = remote_dataset.delete_metadata_properties(["terms-metadata", "integer-metadata", "float-metadata"])
  # Alternative 2 -> via `delete` in-place
  for metadata_property in remote_dataset.metadata_properties:
    deleted_metadata_property = metadata_property.delete()
  ```

**Type of change**

- [X] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [x] Add unit tests for `delete_metadata_properties` on `FeedbackDataset` (local only)
- [x] Add integration tests for `delete_metadata_properties` on `RemoteFeedbackDataset` (remote only)
- [x] Add integration tests for `_RemoteMetadataProperty.delete` via `RemoteTermsMetadataProperty`, `RemoteIntegerMetadataProperty`, and `RemoteFloatMetadataProperty`.
- [x] Add integration tests for `delete_metadata_property` in the Python SDK

title: [BUG] `push_to_argilla` does not accept missing values for optional `TextField`s

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
When a `TextField` of a Feedback dataset is not `required`, it is supposed to accept records that do not have items for the non-required field. However, while pushing such datasets to the server, it throws an error that states that the record has `NoneType` for the missing item rather than proceeding. Since there might be datasets that do not have items for all fields, it might be better if such datasets are accepted.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**
```python
# a dataset that has a mandatory field and an optional field
ds = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[
        rg.TextField(name="text1", required=True),
        rg.TextField(name="text2", required=False),
    ],
    questions=[
        rg.TextQuestion(name="question1", description="This is the first question"),
    ]
)

# this works perfectly as expected
record_with_text2 = rg.FeedbackRecord(
    fields={"text1": "This is the first text", "text2": "This is the second text"},
)

# this would be a possible dataitem that a user would submit, which will raise an error
record_with_no_text2 = rg.FeedbackRecord(
    fields={"text1": "This is the first text"},
)

# no problem adding it to the dataset
ds.add_records([record_with_no_text2])

# this will raise an error
remote_dataset = ds.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="admin")
```
```bash
Exception: Failed while adding the records to the `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla with exception: Argilla server 
returned an error with http status: 422
Error details: [{'response': "Wrong value found for field 'text2'. Expected 'str', found 'NoneType'", 'params': 
{}}]
```

**Expected behavior**
The dataset should be uploaded with the missing values as they are optional. Or, it can be something like `NA`, as well. 

<!-- Since version 1.16.0 you can use `python -m argilla info` command to easily get the used versions -->
**Environment:**
│  • Client version: 1.17.0-dev
│  • Server version: 1.14.1
│  • ElasticSearch version: 8.8.2

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: Feature: add allowed roles to metadata properties
body:
This PR add `allowed_roles` for metadata properties.

This has the potential to affect additional endpoints associated with metadata properties which are still not merged on the feature branch.

If you think this change will affect anything please say something to me and we can discuss about the possible/necessary refactors.

I have updated the draft with the following changes:
* The endpoint `/api/v1/datasets/{dataset.id}/metadata-properties` has been changed to `/api/v1/me/datasets/{dataset.id}/metadata-properties`. (this change should be reflected on the SDK if we are finally accepting the draft @alvarobartt).
* We are internally using `allowed_roles` as a JSON column to store a list of allowed roles to access one specific metadata property.
  * `allowed_roles` is right now an internal column and is not exposed in the API.
* A new `visible_for_annotators` boolean value is accepted to create metadata properties from the API.
  * When `visible_for_annotators` is set as `True` we store `[UserRole.admin, UserRole.annotator]` on `allowed_roles`.
  * When `visible_for_annotators` is set as `False` we store `[UserRole.admin]` on `allowed_roles`.
  * If not specified, `visible_for_annotators` is `True` so admins and annotators has access to the metadata property. (@frascuchon tell me if this is not the expected behavior).
  * `visible_for_annotators` is exposed in the API as a calculated value using `allowed_roles` (as a property on the database model).

title: [DOCS] Update Python API reference with inherited methods

labels.name: type: documentation
labels.description: Improvements or additions to documentation

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

body:
## Which page or section is this issue related to?
The documentation in the Python API [here](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/reference/python/python_client.html#argilla.client.feedback.dataset.local.FeedbackDataset) is extremely lacking. The sphinx autodoc needs to be configured to also include inherited methods. Beyond that, we renamed/moved a bunch of classes. I've resolved the renaming/moving issues with this snippet which goes [here](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blob/develop/docs/_source/reference/python/python_client.rst#feedbackdataset):
```
FeedbackDataset
---------------

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.dataset.local
   :members: FeedbackDataset

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.dataset.remote.dataset
   :members: RemoteFeedbackDataset, RemoteFeedbackRecords

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.dataset.mixins
   :members: ArgillaMixin, UnificationMixin

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.integrations.huggingface
   :members: HuggingFaceDatasetMixin

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.schemas.questions
   :members: RatingQuestion, TextQuestion, LabelQuestion, MultiLabelQuestion, RankingQuestion, QuestionSchema

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.schemas.fields
   :members: TextField, FieldSchema

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.schemas.records
   :members: FeedbackRecord, RemoteFeedbackRecord, ResponseSchema, SuggestionSchema, ValueSchema, RankingValueSchema

.. automodule:: argilla.client.feedback.config
   :members: DatasetConfig
```

The API reference is by far the most important part of any documentation. Keeping it up to date is super important.

- Tom Aarsen

title: feat: update `FilteredRemoteFeedbackRecords.__len__` method

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

This PR updates the `__len__` method of the `FilteredRemoteFeedbackRecords` to return the real number of records matching the filters. To do so, we're not using any special endpoint but the list dataset records with `offset=0` and `limit=0`.

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

In a local development environment:

```python
import random
import argilla as rg

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[
        rg.TextField(name="text")
    ],
    questions=[
        rg.TextQuestion(name="question", required=True)
    ],
    metadata_properties=[
        rg.TermsMetadataProperty(name="letters", values=["a", "b", "c"])
    ]
)

records = [rg.FeedbackRecord(
        fields={"text": "Hello world!" * random.randint(5, 50)},
        responses=[{"values": {"question": {"value": "Hello world!" * random.randint(5, 50)}}}],
        metadata={"letters": random.choice(["a", "b", "c"])}
    ) for _ in range(100000)]

dataset.add_records(records)
remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="random-dataset-2", workspace="gabriel")
filtered_dataset = remote_dataset.filter_by(metadata_filters=[rg.TermsMetadataFilter(name="letters", values=["a"])])
len(filtered_dataset) # ~= 33000
```

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

This feature has been requested by @dvsrepo so that we're able to list all the datasets for a given workspace via an intuitive method such as `list_datasets`.

The current approach is `rg.FeedbackDataset.list(workspace="argilla")` but that's to list just the `FeedbackDataset` datasets and may be not as intuitive as `Workspace(name="argilla").list_datasets()`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Ideally we should add a `list_datasets` method to list all the datasets from a given workspace.

**Additional context**

We should clearly see how to combine both the `FeedbackDataset` with the previous datasets i.e. `DatasetForTextClassification`, `DatasetForTokenClassification` and `DatasetForText2Text`. And also evaluate whether we should be returning just the `name` and `type` of those or a class instance if working with `FeedbackDataset` datasets, etc.
